awd_titl_txt: Workshop:Facets of Integrability: Random Patterns, Stochastic Processes, Hydrodynamics, Gauge Theories and Condensed Matter Systems-the Simons Ctr for Geometry&Physics 1/21-27/2013
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a proposal for partial funding for an international workshop "Facets of integrability: random patterns, stochastic processes, hydrodynamics,gauge theories and condensed matter systems" at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics in January 21-27, 2013. The main goal of the workshop is to establish and investigate relations between random processes and mathematical structures known in classical and quantum integrability. The workshop will focus on various applications of techniques of integrable non-linear systems to random matrices, Dyson diffusion, and counting problems of various geometrical objects arising in random processes, among other topics. The field of integrability is known for being at the interface between mathematics and physics. The influence flows in both directions, with mathematical techniques and ideas contributing crucially to major advances in the theory of integrability. The workshop will bring together mathematicians and physicists who work on ideas related to these fields. The participants will be prominent scientists, young researchers, and students from all over the world.  The Simons Center is most suitable for hosting the proposed workshop. It is a research center devoted to bringing mathematicians and physicists together to further fundamental knowledge in geometry and theoretical physics, especially knowledge at the interface of these two disciplines.  For broader impact the results presented at the workshop will be recorded and disseminated through a web site of the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, which is a very natural place to host such a workshop, being located in close proximity to Mathematics and Physics departments of Stony Brook University and to the Yang Institute for Theoretical Physics, with a tradition of excellence in the field of integrability. 

The main idea of the workshop is to bring together people working in different fields. The cross-fertilization of different fields provides a nice environment for training graduate students and postdocs. Junior researchers will be especially encouraged to participate using NSF support to pay for their for travel and lodging. Supporting the travel of young researchers and graduate students to such a conference where scientists from different scientific fields, old and young, prominent and just beginning, are spending a week in an inspiring and congenial environment will, as it has done so in the past, inspire many beginning researchers, including minorities and members from the underrepresented groups. By prompt advertising and by offering partial travel support it will significantly increase the participation of young students and researchers.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop entitled Facets of Integrability: Random Patterns, Stochastic Processes, Hydrodynamics, Gauge Theories and Condensed Matter Systems was at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, Stony Brook University from January 21-27, 2013 as a part of the longer visiting program on Conformal Geometry at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics. Organized by Ilia Binder, Andrei Okounkov, Alexander Abanov, Eldad Bettelheim, Ilya Gruzberg, Seung-Yeop Lee and Razvan Teodoresc, the primary goal of the workshop was to narrow gaps between seemingly different disciplines in mathematics and physics that share similar integrable structures. The second part of the workshop was more focused on novel applications of integrability in conformal field theories, gauge theory, and non-equilibrium phenomena. It also included a celebration of Paul Wiegmann’s 60th birthday.

This was a 7-day workshop with 4 one-hour talks per day with the Sunday morning reserved for the continuation of informal discussions. Participants constituted a mix of physicists and mathematicians with the schedule designed to encourage active discussions between representatives of different fields. The workshop focused on application of integrable structures of quantum and classical systems to various modern topics in geometry, combinatorics and stochastic processes. Topics covered in talks included: random processes governed by conformal invariance such as Laplacian growth, counting problems of various geometrical objects arising in random processes, applications of tau-functions and Painleve transcendents, BPS/CFT correspondence, Hirota dynamics, universal Whitham hierarchy and applications of conformal field theory.

The workshop included SCGP-Math colloquium “Deep waters of quantum cohomology” given by Andrei Okounkov and many review talks given among others by P. Di Francesco, A. Its, J. Harnad, and I. Krichever. All presentations were recorded and were well attended by a varied audience.  According to exit interviews of participants the workshop was very successful with the right mixture of talks of different style and from different fields. All participants also praised a scientific environment of the Simons Center, the efficiency of the staff of the Center and the high quality of meals provided by the Simons Café. Many participants expressed that the organization of the workshop was excellent, with a great arrangement of speakers, one stating, "there was a variety of very interesting talks in very different well-chosen topics and I learned something new from each of them." The Simons Center’s goal of interface between the disciplines of mathematics and physics was achieved in this workshop as "physicists really tried to be understandable to mathematicians" and vice versa. The participants thought that it was "convenient that video and slides are available online."

The workshop was extended compared to the standard SCGP workshops. The additional funding came from NSF allowed to bring more of younger researchers and graduate students to the workshop and a contribution from the University of Chicago allowed to celebrate Paul Wiegmann’s research achievements on the occasion of his 60th birthday.
